greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Number of 2's in the last section of the set of partitions of n.
comment: Essentially the same as A087787 but here a(n) is the number of 2's in the last section of n, not n-2. See also A100818.
Note that a(1)..a(11) coincide with a(2)..a(12) of A005291.
Also number of 2's in all partitions of n that do not contain 1's as a part, if n >= 1. Also 0 together with the first differences of A024786. - _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 13 2011
Also number of 2's in the n-th section of the set of partitions of any integer >= n. For the definition of "section" see A135010. - _Omar E. Pol_, Dec 01 2013
link: Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..1000
formula: It appears that A000041(n) = a(n+1) + a(n+2), n >= 0. - _Omar E. Pol_, Feb 04 2012
example: a(6) = 4 counts the 2's in 6 = 4+2 = 2+2+2. The 2's in 6 = 3+2+1 = 2+2+1+1 = 2+1+1+1+1 do not count. - _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 13 2011

In the last section of the set of partitions of 6 the difference between the sum of the second column and the sum of the third column is 8 - 4 = 4, the same as the number of 2's, so a(6) = 4 (see also A024786).
program: (Sage) A182712 = lambda n: sum(list(p).count(2) for p in Partitions(n) if 1 not in p) # _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 13 2011
results.author: _Omar E. Pol_, Nov 28 2010
